biography

Early Life

I was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, on December 12, 2003. In my early years, I attended preschool and then Fulton Elementary School from kindergarten through 5th grade. This period was incredibly important to me because of the environment I was in. I often credit elementary school as the happiest time I ever had as a student. The principal, Mr. Bivens, along with the teachers and academic staff, spent a lot of time building trust with their students and rewarding us for our achievements. I remember that every month, we had field trips and school challenges. We learned about sustainability, manners, and, most importantly, how to learn. Learning itself was something we were rewarded for. Throughout elementary school, I consistently achieved High Honor Roll, and I graduated at the top of my class, even delivering a commencement speech.

During this time, I developed an interest in a variety of things, such as building with LEGO or virtual development platforms, as well as drawing—mainly ships like the Titanic and other warships that fascinated me. Unlike many kids my age, I wasn't drawn to Disney Channel or Nickelodeon. Instead, I preferred watching the History Channel, captivated by stories of great battles and ancient dynasties. Something about it just felt more engaging than Dora the Explorer. This curiosity and love for learning stuck with me throughout elementary school and beyond, shaping my entire academic journey.

Middle school, however, was a much more challenging time for me. I struggled with my grandmother's declining health and the influences of my friends. While I managed to keep up academically, it wasn't at a level I was comfortable with. I don't remember much from middle school, but overall, it was a subpar experience—one I'm not particularly eager to revisit.

High School

I think those of us who experienced high school when I did had a truly unique journey. COVID didn't ruin my high school experience, but it did shorten it. Despite this, I consider this phase of my life to be when I gained a greater understanding of the world. My passion for history deepened, but I also began to truly appreciate the power of STEM. Throughout all four years, I was part of a Videography class, which became a key part of my STEM education. I also pushed myself academically, taking Advanced Placement courses. While the curriculum only required me to go up to Trigonometry, I challenged myself and finished with Calculus AB (Calculus I). However, where I truly fell in love with STEM was in my Physics class. My physics teacher played a huge role in helping me grasp the fundamentals of classical mechanics, guiding me through every step of the learning process.

Beyond academics, high school was where I discovered the person I wanted to be. I became a well-rounded, moderate individual who could connect with different kinds of people and navigate various friend groups. This not only helped me avoid conflicts but also exposed me to different perspectives, making me a more open-minded person. By my senior year, I had taken on multiple leadership roles, serving as Student Council Treasurer, Director of the Penn Hills Media Team, and Vice President of the National Honor Society. Additionally, I helped secure $10,000 in grant funding for a documentary on COVID's impact on high school life.

College

College has arguably been the most important and rewarding chapter of my life thus far. I have had the honor of being awarded the Michael Lomax Student Success Scholarship at Morehouse College, which covers tuition along with room and board. Additionally, I have been accepted into notable organizations such as Sigma Pi Sigma for physicists and am a member of the American Physical Society, the National Society of Black Engineers, and the National Society of Black Physicists. I am also part of the Howard Thurman Honors Program and have been given the opportunity to work as a research assistant at Georgia Tech with Flavio Fenton in the CHAOS Lab. Academically, I have been challenged in the world of STEM, with professors rigorously assigning work and exams to ensure we master the material. If elementary school built the foundation for academics, middle school established my social skills, and high school merged the two, then college is where I have truly put them to work.

Socially, college has been a rollercoaster, filled with opportunities to form lifelong friendships and engage in meaningful conversations about serious topics. It has been inspiring to be surrounded by ambitious individuals who push themselves to rise to the occasion—yet the admiration is always mutual. People recognize your efforts, talk about your achievements, and want to learn about you just as you do about them. This environment of collaboration is one of the most beautiful aspects of college, as we all work toward learning, growing, and making the most of our time before entering the workforce. We uplift each other through challenges, whether it's supporting a friend on the verge of failing a class or learning humility when proven wrong. College teaches more than just academics—it teaches you how to navigate shared spaces, think globally, and be more conscious of the world around you. I've learned invaluable lessons from my time in college and truly enjoy every moment of it.

hobbies

Photography

Photography is a cornerstone of my life—a passion that first emerged in high school through Videography I and II, followed by two years in Advanced Studio Broadcast, where I learned the fundamentals of crafting a good scene and developed my own artistic taste. After graduating in 2022, I ventured into photography with a Canon Rebel, eventually upgrading to a Fujifilm X-T4 paired with a 35mm F1.4 lens. My goal is to create images with character—photos that tell a story with a vintage, retro aesthetic while exploring unconventional angles and perspectives. Street photography is my primary focus, and I like to think I've developed a strong eye for it. Through my work, I aim to capture the essence of a moment, making the ordinary feel cinematic.

Cooking

Another cornerstone of my life is my love for cooking. I vividly remember the first time I ever made anything—scrambled eggs at my grandma's house. Growing up, my early culinary experiments were often absurd, sometimes downright disastrous, but that was the first time I created something truly edible. My mom wasn't the best cook—though I'd never admit that to her—but over time, I took it upon myself to cook more and more. Now, I have a broad range of spices, meals, and flavor combinations at my disposal, constantly refining my skills and expanding my repertoire in the kitchen.

Game Development

Game development actually grew out of my love for LEGO as a child. I always craved more creativity, more freedom, and more ways to solve problems or build something intricate. My solution was to transition to Minecraft, where I could push my creative limits even further. Eventually, I moved on to ROBLOX and its game development platform, which offered nearly unlimited possibilities for building and scripting. Through ROBLOX, I learned the principles of 3D modeling and gained experience with rudimentary coding using Lua+, laying the foundation for my interest in game development.

History Enthusiast

History has always been a longstanding interest of mine, and I would even classify it as a hobby. It's not just about learning the past but also about collecting the tangible pieces of it. Over time, I've gathered historical artifacts and collectibles, including a 1940s camera, a 1907 edition of Tom Sawyer, collectible action figures, and discontinued items passed down by my uncle, Mr. Tommy, and other family members. Beyond the collectibles, history gives me a deeper understanding of the world today—why things are the way they are and how the past continues to shape the present.

goals

5yr Goal

In five years I have two paths that I want to go down. The first is the graduate route and the second is the industry route. If I was to go down the graduate program I would like to either get a masters or PhD in Electrical Engineering or Pure Physics. If I was to go down in industry I would like to work either in a National Research Laboratory or a startup company.

10yr Goal

My philosophy is I do not think this far ahead but in 10 years I may eyeball science policy or even olitics. If I don't already enjoy the job I am working in or if I enjoy the interactions I have with customers I would like to join the policy side of making the most of my education to influence policy decisions.
